2 Chron Chap 26

11 Uzziah had a well-trained army, ready to go out by divisions according to their numbers as mustered by Jeiel the secretary and Maaseiah the officer under the direction of Hananiah, one of the royal officials.

12 The total number of family leaders over the fighting men was 2,600.

13 Under their command was an army of 307,500 men trained for war, a powerful force to support the king against his enemies.

14 Uzziah provided shields, spears, helmets, coats of armor, bows and slingstones for the entire army.

15 In Jerusalem he made devices invented for use on the towers and on the corner defenses so that soldiers could shoot arrows and hurl large stones from the walls. His fame spread far and wide, for he was greatly helped until he became powerful.

16 But after Uzziah became powerful, his pride led to his downfall. He was unfaithful to the Lord his God, and entered the temple of the Lord to burn incense on the altar of incense.

17 Azariah the priest with eighty other courageous priests of the Lord followed him in.

18 They confronted King Uzziah and said, “It is not right for you, Uzziah, to burn incense to the Lord. That is for the priests, the descendants of Aaron, who have been consecrated to burn incense. Leave the sanctuary, for you have been unfaithful; and you will not be honored by the Lord God.”

19 Uzziah, who had a censer in his hand ready to burn incense, became angry. While he was raging at the priests in their presence before the incense altar in the Lord’s temple, leprosy[c] broke out on his forehead.

20 When Azariah the chief priest and all the other priests looked at him, they saw that he had leprosy on his forehead, so they hurried him out. Indeed, he himself was eager to leave, because the Lord had afflicted him.

21 King Uzziah had leprosy until the day he died. He lived in a separate house[d]—leprous, and banned from the temple of the Lord. Jotham his son had charge of the palace and governed the people of the land.

From U.K. My home town of Rotherham Yorkshire was home to the Walker company who manufactured most of this countries iron cannon from the mid 18th century onwards. By the end of the 18th century 22’000 heavy guns per year were leaving the town, many for export including America. They can be identified by the logo ‘W co’ cast into the end of the left trunnion. If anyone comes across one, our local civic society and myself would be grateful for the information. 
Fun fact: Back in the day, a by-product of cannon making was tourism. Before delivery each gun needed to be test fired. Occasionally a casting fault would result in the gun exploding and sending lumps of iron skywards. On these test firing days, thousands of visitors from all over the country would fill the town, all hoping to see a gun explode. The town centre filled with pubs to accommodate the visitors.

Destin, there is most certainly a LOT going on in firing rounds from a cannon.  Very interesting!  For instance...did you notice an initial ejection of gasses are followed by another more intense explosive burst of gases, with the projectile seemingly flying through both?  Since most cannons used in the war were smoothbore, I assume these are as well.  Those initial bursts must be gases that must have moved around and ahead of the projectile, exiting first.  Also I found out that some cannon rounds were hollow...filled with powder & various sized balls...and they were fused.  The fuses could be set to explode in the air, upon impact or as the round was rolling in between the ranks of solders.  Quite brutal.

Why are there two explosions out of the front of the cannon?  I see one pre-explosion and then a larger one that propels the projectile down range.  I also see a LOT of unburnt powder...are they putting too much in the barrel or is the cannon not efficiently sealing the projectile and allowing bypass gas and powder to get ahead of the round?  I know that the same principle is dangerous with a .45/70 round where the black powder charge can cause a backfire within the cartridge if you don't use a cardboard plug to keep the blackpowder to the rear of the cartridge.  Without the cardboard plug, the powder lays down in the cartridge and fire goes faster over the top of the powder pile and then ignites the unburnt powder causing a backwards explosion and possibly injury to the shooter.  Just a thought or two...

So God Bless U guys and what U do . I am fascinated  by the amount of powder and smoke that leaves the barrel before the projectile. I spent 23 years in the Army and worked with almost every type of weapon at our disposal and had the honor of working with many foreign weapons for comparison and familiarization. Was an awesome time.  With all our modern weaponry the barrel had a system of lands and grooves in order to seal the round in the barrel and impart spin for range and accuracy. Then along came the M1A1A2 and the rhinemetal    120mm smooth bore cannon.  The point to all this is if we had ever seen that much powder and smoke and flame in front of the projectile, it would be time to re-tube. The other cool thing is how inertia, or resistance to acceleration allows the cannon to be fired safely.  When the cannon fires, all that amazing force only causes it to roll back about 5-10 feet.  Two men can easily roll the cannon back to it's starting place without exerting all that much effort but if they had tried to stop the cannonball that caused the rollback in the first place they would be obliterated.  All because when they roll it back to the firing line they are accelerating it very slowly while when the cannonball fires it is causing very rapid acceleration backwards.  Way more energy involved.  Since the mass of the cannon doesn't change, the difference in force required (F=ma) is all due to the difference in acceleration.

This is an utterly remarkable video... thanks for making it.  I make cannon carriages... and restore Civil War cannons.  I've never seen the dynamics of recoil on a carriage.  It's fantastic.   The development that went into the Civil War cannon was 500 years of engineering.... the world's BEST engineering at the time.   Military academies were, basically, artillery schools.  Because it was where the mathematicians, scientists, engineers.... best and the brightest went.   And they designed these implements of war.  Just after the CW... Iron carriages, hydraulic recoil, cordite, breech loading.... all came about.  So these carriages are the penultimate development of wood-carriage artillery.  Amazing video.  Thanks so much for making it and sharing it!

Fun fact: The speed of recoil of a gun is the speed of the bullet divided by the ratio of gun/bullet weight.
Gun weighs 100 pounds, bullet weighs 1 pound. 100:1 ratio.
If the Bullet is doing 600 feet per second at the muzzle, the gun is recoiling at 6 feet per second the other way.
Conservation of momentum and all that!
Since using a chronograph to measure muzzle-velocity is tricky due to muzzle blast, measuring the speed of gun recoil should be a lot simpler.

As a Civil War reenactor, I primarily did infantry. I've been in a trench in front of cannons, with them firing overhead, about 10 feet above us. There's no way of explaining how hard that shockwave is. Every few cannon shots, we'd have to shuffle our feet to keep from being buried in the dirt falling to the bottom of the trench. But then I decided to join a cannon crew. I got trained for all the positions and spent a reenacting season as a cannoneer. At a firing range, we tried out a canister round against a bunch of plywood human cutout targets. Match sticks. That's all that remained. It's horrifying. It's quite literally a giant shotgun shell. There are reports from the Civil War of soldiers literally disintegrating, leaving the soldier next to them untouched. All that remained of the other soldier were smoking shoes. Imagine that. No way of identifying the body. No way of keeping record of which soldier died where. Nothing to send the family. Nothing left to remember them by. No way to lay them to rest. Cannoneers would know they had a direct hit with a canister round, by the red mist hanging in the air after their shot. The devastation caused by these cannons are the reason why when the attacking forces overtook a cannon's position, the cannoneers would flee, leaving the cannons behind. Infantry would be treated respectfully. Cannoneers would be killed, because of the amount of casualties and devastation they caused.

I would highly recommend everyone to go to a Civil War reenactment, and talk to the reenactors. All of us have lots of information, and we love sharing it. We also love recruiting people into reenacting. I learned more about the Civil War and WWII (I switched to WWII) in two days, than I did in 4 years of history class. Being there and experiencing the lifestyle first hand is a much better teacher than reading out of any book. Talk to any reenactor and ask them how to get involved, and they'll happily help you get started. Reenacting is great for men and women, and children as well. The powder monkey (carries the round/charge during the loading process) is usually between 12 and 17 years old.

Years ago, a bunch of guys from my church (all Civil War buffs) went and saw a cannon demonstration up close (yes, I was there). Man those things raise your pulse! They were very professional, they made us stay back I think 55 feet, because if the cannon ruptured (it was a larger Napoleon) it wouldn't throw anything past that (probably). The captain preferred the smoothbores because they were made of brass which wouldn't fragment, rather it would vent, which could still kill people, but only on the side that it split on.
He explained lots and answered questions. I wish I had a video camera at the time. They showed all of the steps involved, from loading the charge, to piercing the powder bag (with a special tool), to putting in the friction trigger. It was awesome.
(I live in Monmouth County, NJ, and we used to have re-enactments of the Battle of Monmouth, Revolutionary War, and they would fire even older cannons at targets on the hillside. I'm not sure if it still happens.)
